thread.title: Hartland, Howell equestrian advance to state finals
thread.title_full: Hartland, Howell equestrian advance to state finals

title: Hartland, Howell equestrian advance to state finals
text:
Hartland, Howell equestrian advance to state finals Anthony Odoardi 9:27 p.m. EDT October 5, 2015 The Hartland equestrian team came in second its group at regionals and will advance to the state finals Oct. 14-18. (Photo: Submitted Photo) CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Entering the Sunday, the final day of regionals for Michigan's high school equestrian teams, Hartland believed it to be all but over. For the second straight year, it was sure it would fall short of the state finals once again. 
Eagles coach Marcia Deyoung gathered her team that afternoon at lunch and told them what it was going to take in order to make that leap from fifth place in second, the qualifying spot to reach states. 
"We thought it was a longshot," Deyoung said. "I pretty much said, basically, 'Yeah, you need to place very well (in Sunday's competitions) to make it. And oh yeah, it was a surprise thing at the end." 
It took a nearly-perfect day to make that climb, for the Eagles to avoid the same fate as 2014 — when they fell 16 points short of being named the Division A Reserve Champions, what equestrian teams refer to as second place — and, somehow, they got it. 
With a total of 326 points, Hartland made the cut, coming in behind the Divison A Grand Champions, Goodrich, which scored 437 points. Howell also made the cut in Division B, the Highlanders winning their region with 481 points. 
Both schools will partake in the state finals from Oct. 14-18 in Midland. 
Brighton, which competed in Howell's group, missed the cut with a sixth-place finish. 
"Oh, the kids were really happy," Deyoung said. "We were all really happy." 
Hartland's Rylee Burke (55) and Dawson Deyoung (55) led the Eagles in scoring. 
For the Eagles, it marks their first trip to the state finals since 2011. Only one rider on the team was part of the 2011 group; however, the coach said she felt her team had the experience to make it a successful trip. 
Whether or not it can win is yet to be seen. That could also be viewed as a longshot considering Goodrich's impressive score of 437. The 111-point margin of victory isn't something Hartland's accustomed to seeing. 
"We hate it when someone is 100 points ahead of us, because we know we struggled to get caught up and beat them," Marcia Deyoung said. "I would say they were really good with good riders and good horses, but we did have some issues. 
"Cold, nasty, windy weather, which was also an issue because the horses don't perform as well cause we're outside. That's the same for everybody, I know. But I would say we definitely had some mistakes we need to work on." 
Asked what it will take to correct those mistakes and Marcia Deyoung said: "A lot of hard work." 
"It's all patterns, so it's very hard," the Hartland coach said, "and basically at this point, you have all the top riders and teams there in the whole state." 
And while they might not might not win, the Eagles know they're one of them. Read or Share this story: http://ldpaa.com/1RrEaim TOP VIDEOS
